reviewText:
I just finished watching Good Neighbors, I gotta say, I was pleasantly surprised. It is a really good and entertaining suspense drama, that is mostly Character driven.
the story follows three main characters that live in the same apartment complex, each living their own lives, and getting to know each other as friendly neighbors. At the same time, their seems to be a serial killer in the same area, which creates tention among those characters.
Sure the movie has a slow pace to it, but it really keeps your attention and never feels boring, I personally enjoyed it, and thought that the best thing about this movie are the characters, whom each had thier own twisted personalities, own agendas and different lives though living in the same complex.
the film displays and demonstrates humans and their behaviors, how much self centered we can be. all characters were smart, but selfish and had secrets hidden despite acting as good neighbors. brilliant human nature display here.
the director managed to capture and create a dark suspensful atmosphere, relying on the cold snowy and depressing Canadian winter, and at the same time, offered some relief with some funny moments and some what lovable and mysterious characters.
overall, it was a dark suspensful drama, with interesting characters played very well with some talented actors, keeps you guessing and intrigued as events unfold.
I highly recommend this. 4.5 stars.
the ending however, might leave much to be desired.

I rented this movie over the internet not certain how good it would be. I didn't read any reviews on it, so I went in cold. Wow, was I suprised. Strong characters, tight plot, no funny camera tricks, no red herrings, no gratuitous frights... just a straight up cat and mouse murder mystery that is absorbing, ironic with a few moments of laughter in it. I have to say, there hasn't been one like this in many years.
I believe going in on this one blind made the difference because if I had read anything about it I may have been mislead. If you like murder mysteries this one is for you. I'm not going to give away the plot, that's already been done in other reviews. I will just say this is a fresh look and twist on the cat and mouse murder mystery that is worth seeing. Thoroughly enjoyable! Highly recommended.

GOOD NEIGHBORS is an original noirish-style thriller focusing on a quartet of neighbors in a Montreal apartment complex.  We meet Louise (Emily Hampshire), a waitress in a Chinese restaurant with a strong attachment to her two cats; Spencer (Scott Speedman), a wheelchair-bound cynic who likes tropical fish; Victor (Jay Baruchel), the nerdy newcomer who develops an attachment to Louise; and Valerie, the foul-mouthed lady who hates Louise's cats and complains about everything.
A serial rapist/killer is terrorizing the city and how these characters figure in the mix forms the core of the movie's narrative.  To reveal more would spoil the film's clever plot twists.  The movie has a slow pace but holds your attention as it reaches its unexected climax.  The performances are uniformly very good and there's a sinister eeriness that accentuates the mood of the film.  GOOD NEIGHBORS is a refreshing change of pace in an ofen tired genre.
kept me interested through to the end.  Loved how your perspective about each character changes as the movie progressed. The ending was a bit frustrating.

A unique bit of suspenseful storytelling with a touch of black cat comedy in which I don't recall having seen this plot before and for that reason and for the realistic portrayals by the actors I give a nearly perfect score. The exception is not because of any horrific scenes, of which they were all implied, but for the lack of an alternate ending amongst which I would have preferred one particular ending.

So, here is my thought on ending the movie. Since semen was on the cat hating (actually hating everything and one) person's body the police should have, but didn't (in their customary dumb ass movie portrayal) collect and compare amongst all the victims. Having done so they would have found two killers and not one. That would have left only the latest killer to pursue her cat loving ways. Thus, one killer down, one innocent (but has a character that is better for it) in jail, and one free to create a sequel.

The movie starts out slow. In fact I was ready to turn it off a few times and watch "Flying Nun" reruns. But it is just attempting to establish character, at least the character we normally see without secrets. The "action" takes place in an apartment building with 3 English speaking people living in French Canada. Louise (Emily Hampshire) lives alone with 2 cats with which she has bonded. The rest of her neighbors loathe her cats. She works at a local Chinese restaurant within walking distance.

Spencer (Scott Speedman) is a large blond confined to a wheel chair. We later find out he was married and his wife died in the same wreak that confined him to said chair. He is considered a hunk by the older women in the building and they suspect that he and Louise would one day get together. He loves fish (live or cooked). He has anger management issues which sometimes slip out. While he is in a wheel chair, his legs are normal as there appears to be no reason for him to be in the wheel chair.

Victor (Jay Baruchel) is the new guy in the building. He is a bit spastic and is irritating with his constant chatter. He develops a love for Emily which is not returned.

There is a serial killer in the city and Louise is obsessed with the thought as her friend at the cafe was a recent victim. The victim had a date that night with a large blond guy named "Roland." A large guy named "Roland" is also conducting the investigation. The French Canadian woman who lives in the building is shown in a bad light and provides some inner conflict.

As events unfolded and made the characters more interesting and improbable, I found myself still waiting for things to happen. Magnolia generally does the feel good Indie films with a fitting lame acoustical sound track. In this film they were clueless about a decent sound track, something that would have added to the film. I would not call this a "noir" film or a "thriller" as does the DVD hype. It is an indie with typical quirky characters, a movie heavy on building characters and light on action. Might make for a rental if you really love Indie films and cats.

F-bomb, sex, nudity. The rating claims "strong violence and graphic nudity" which are perhaps over statements. There is one violent scene without a close up and one weird nude scene with Emily Hampshire in the dark.
The movie is well done.  Not predictable.  Not satisfying in a visceral way, but thought provoking. I would recommend it.

I hesitated to spend the $3.99 after reading the one and only other review of this movie but am glad I threw caution to the wind and maybe my money. Good Neighbors is a really entertaining movie.  It's a bit off-beat and quirky but great characters, well acted and very interesting. I thought the dialogue was fun and the relationship between the three main characters engrossing. Give this movie a chance, you won't be disappointed.

"A woman your age should always be concerned for her safety, it's a
nasty world." Victor (Baruchel) has just moved to Montreal in the
middle of a killing spree by a serial killer. He meets his new
neighbors Louise and Spencer (Speedman) and does his best to become
friends with them. Soon secrets are revealed. I will start by saying
that I did enjoy this movie. The big problem with it is that it was
very flat all the way through. Never got bad enough to stop watching
and trying to figure out the killer made you want to keep watching till
the end. The movie never really got to an exciting point where you are
totally engrossed in it. I can't really say anything bad about this
because I did like it, but I can't say anything good about it because
it was slow and drawn out with very little action. Overall, not a bad
movie so worth a watch. Not a good movie so don't rush to watch it
though. I give it a B-.

Would I watch again? - I don't think so.

*Also try - Perfect Host

Good neighbors is insultingly predictable, with stilted dialogue and bizarre-o bad acting. I watched forty-five minutes, and when what I'd been predicting happened, I went online to read reviews. Another reviewer mentioned that the film becomes sickening to watch. Considering the serial rapist murderer plot, and the exorbitant amount of time spent showing the main character's love of her cats, there were enough ingredients for gruesome visuals, which I am extremely unfond of.  There was no point continuing on with an increasingly klutzy film, with nary a thrill to be found - just the unearned dread of something nasty. The question this movie poses is, "Who can you trust?" A thriller could have been made around the query without resorting to the old hat, crime TV stand-by: brutal violence against women. Don't waste your time on this brain numbing mess.
Awesome movie! I love Scott Speedman.!! This is a must watch...
surprised very good.
Fantastic
entertaining flick!
Watched this after a recommendation from a friend. I'd give it a C-
ok
This movie is for those with a dark sense of humor.  Good story, liked the actors.  Very entertaining
Good movie. Didn't like the ending.

I enjoyed this movie quite a bit. I thought each of the three main characters was the killer at one point, so that kept me attentive to the story line. Who knew so many people with major problems would all be living in the same apartment building? Entertaining movie!
bad movie, a kind of disgusting. and I love "vampire diaries" or "walking dead" but this movie is really bad.
Interesting. I liked it.
You kinda know who from the getgo - bit cheesy - but good story

Ah, the typical three characters, the desperate guy, loner girl with more cats than friends, and the Dr. Jekyll/Mr. Hyde guy. Giving the movie 3 stars is being generous considering the plot was more predictable than suspenseful. You will know who the characters are, and their roles in the story, within the first 5 minutes. I didn't hate it but I didn't love it.
Slow in the first 15 minutes of the movie.  Keeps you thinking as to "Who and Why"?
Great movie.
More crap from Canada.
Excellent movie.

All of the character development was half-hearted and resulted in quite possibly the most irritating and loathsome trio in more than a decade. The story was boring also under developed. This film could have been quite decent, instead I was terribly bored and moderately irritated with myself for even watching the whole thing.
Like an old fashioned whodunnit.  Keeps you guessing for a while. It's ok to kill some time.
Very good movie with solid character development and a great story. Definitely watch if you get a chance.
Predictable but it was still pretty good. It was a little strange, but that helped make it interesting.
I think they could've made this movie much more interesting. The first half was very slow.
Weird and kinda slow but not bad for free on prime instant video.

I won't lie; the main reason I watched this is because I'm a little obsessed with Scott Speedman. So I gave it an extra star because he's in it. So we're up to two. This was ok as something to half pay attention to while I worked on an art project, but that's it. My boyfriend was unfortunately roped into watching it with me and his rating would be about 1 star (because he does watch a lot of really bad zombie movies so he's got to give this at least some credit.) The storyline kind of had some potential, I was really hoping it would go somewhere cool but they spent way more time building up the weirdness of the characters and maybe 5 minutes of effort into the point of the plot. I felt like whoever wrote it just threw together an ending after getting overly involved in describing just how odd cat-loving Canadians can be. Then they threw in a suspicious and lonely nerd, a hot dude in a wheelchair (or is he..yeah the previews go ahead and give you that answer) who seems to really like fish, for some reason that's never explained, creates a little love triangle (but let's be serious, clearly this chick is way more into cats romantically than humans) some predictable murders, and calls it a day. However, if you're looking for something to use in an argument over whether or not cat people are genuinely some of the strangest people that exist, this is your movie. You WILL win that argument.
Shameful ... The last movie of this genre for me
Interesting story but not too good of a movie.

Great movie. Quirky characters, funny, well acted. The scenes were so good that just what was in the scene with the deadpan of the actors, especially Louise, had me laughing. The whole thing with her and the murder was priceless. I will see this one again.

This held my attention.  Saw some things I've never seen before.  I'm glad I have Prime, I can pause anytime I want to.  There was one seen so gruesome I had to pause and take a break, I was afraid to see what was next.  I loved the SUSPENSE of this move.  I thought the end justified the means.

Very good twists.  I am happy I found this by accident on Prime Instant Video and watched it.  I originally only watched it, because I am a Judd Apatow fan and liked "Undeclared" (which Jay Baruchel starred in with Charlie Hunnam).  I loved Jay in Seth Rogen's "This Is The End", in which everybody plays themselves.
Not worth watching absolute rubbish
Great movie
A very dumb movie aimed at very dumb people.  A lousy Canadian export.

One more movie here that has a very disappointing ending, that leaves you hanging and thinking what was the point.  A movie doesn't have to be fast paced for me, but I do like one with an ending.  This film was a waste of time, and it didn't have to be.
If I could give it no stars I would. This movie suck and so boring
Not the worst movie ever.... Would not watch it twice though. ..
It was slow,  dragged out,  and boring.

Good Neighbors, was gem of a little movie. Normally I ignore most reviews, since I like to make-up my own mind, but this time the reviews sold me! Who doesn't love a good murder mystery, and this one held your interest from beginning to end. Each of the three main characters have their own little quirks and secrets, which are revealed as they are endlessly thrown together. The plot centers around a serial killer still on the loose and how it effects our  little group of players.  I'm proud to say I figured out the killer early in the movie, and you probably will too.  Even knowing this takes nothing from this thriller.  I found the ending to be a bit of a surprise, and whether  the death count continues remains to be seen.  I came away feeling good after seeing this movie and what more could you ask for.
This movie is weird, very boring and kind of predictable. It's get's two stars for Scott.
watched to end but hated myself for doing so....dare if you are courageous
Weird movie. I watched the whole thing but didn't really find much purpose to it.
Twisted!!
predictable
This movie was strange.  The trailer makes it look a whole lot better than it actually is.  Not great, but also not horrible.  However, it is just a few notches above that.
Decent movie takes awhile to get going, ending was good...
OK, but kind of dumb. Interesting plot, but easy to figure.

Good acting and a nice plot! I'm picky about which movies I watch through until the end and this one kept me entertained! I watched this without really knowing what it was about and it was a nice surprise!
Kinda like watching paint dry... Gave up after 45 mins of waiting for something (anything!) to happen.
I like movies like this one with lots of twists and unexpected turns
Nice twisted dark comedy.  The acting is awesome.
Good Movie
good movie fast shipping low price
Already reviewed and stared this!
This movie was a waste of time don't even bother to watch it. Its very slow and dragging and the ending sucks.
Bad acting throughout, predictable, terrible ending
entertaining but I knew spencer could walk early into the movie as well as being the killer but still I watched it thru I liked it.

Ok.. I am from Jonquiere, about 5 hours from Montreal... Considered a Real Quebecois... I saw that movie and even as a real Canadian ,that movie was sooo disgusting.......The French language was foul. a disgrace for me ...please  disregard that awful movie... I am Canadian and proud and i hate this !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Felt the movie was very slow, that the whole movie could have been compressed into a half hour.

Not good but not awful. The plot was weak, the movie itself was dark, but there were some interesting twists. Glad I didn't pay to see this anywhere, but it's also two hours of my life I can't get back.
This movie was EXTREMELY awkward... all in all it was pretty interesting, but i don't think i would recommend it.
All the characters in this movie are a bit odd, or have some quirks that are obvious.  Worth a watch
It was a great mystery. I had no idea who the murderer was until it was revealed! You must see this movie.
This movie is okay. Gave it 2 stars because I did watch the whole movie. I would probably not think to recommend to anyone.
Me & My Fianc Really Liked Watching This Movie So Hopefully Everyone Else Will Like It Also Thanks Amazon Prime!
I hesitate to ask, but here goes...so who was the real serial killer?  Was it Louise? I liked Victor he was a nice person.
An interesting and entertaining film. A classy who-done-it type of movie. Certainly worth watching. Not for animal or pet lovers, however.
Not a bad movie.  Nothing brilliant. Can't think o f much m o 're to say about th I s movie I e. It's just ok.

Well written story-line and plot has many nuances not immediately perceived.  Acting is good though the lead actress has never been one of my favorites for personal reasons best left undisclosed.  For an Indie film this is very well acted, produced, directed, edited, and written.  Since Smoke Signals Gary Farmer has been one of my favorite actors~

I'm not sure what this movie is trying to say, if indeed it's trying to say anything at all.  First the characters are all extremely unlikeable and most are little more than caricatures. Emily Hampshire's character in particular defies all normal and abnormal personality types, managing to be eccentric, socially awkward, neurotic, robotic, and coolly sadistic when the mood suits her.  I'd like to say it's because the character has a lot of depth, but I'm pretty sure it's because playing "guess what strange thing Louise is going to do next" is the only thing driving the movie.  Seriously: take her away and pretty much all that's left is a couple of fish feeding and cat scenes.  I guess they're supposed to symbolize a sort of cat-catches-fish game.  Anyway, a movie called "Good Neighbours" kind of implies that the neighbors will actually be a crucial and interesting part of the plot.  One of the neighbors was a serial killer and they actually managed to make the reveal boring by making it so obvious beforehand.  If I could unwatch it I would: Proceed with caution.

Louise (Emily Hampshire- COSMOPOLIS) lives in an apartment building in Montreal w/ her two cats. She lives above her disabled neighbor, Spencer. One day, a new tenant named Victor (Jay Baruchel- also COSMOPOLIS) moves in. The three have an awkward relationship, since Spencer seems a bit jealous and very tense. Meanwhile, a vicious serial killer is raping and murdering young women in the neighborhood. This fact is made painfully clear when one of Louise's coworkers becomes a victim. Back at the apartment building, Louise's cats are found dead, Victor falls in love w/ Louise, Louise falls in love w/ Victor's cat, a dark secret is revealed, and a diabolical plot is devised. GOOD NEIGHBORS is a semi-comedic, quirky thriller w/ some very interesting twists, and a few rather gruesome turns. Completely different from what I was expecting, and that's a good thing!...
This was different.  It was a good storyline, just amazing at how many lunatics live in one place. But it was a worth while watch.  I think you enjoy the ending.

3 Cats...a Black Widow...a Deranged Serial Killer, and a Geek all adds up to a very suspenseful thriller with exquisite acting and twists and turns that will keep you glued to the screen.  Some reviewers were disappointed in the ending but remember Alfred Hitchcock's success followed similar lines (i.e. The Birds). This was a thrill ride...right up my alley.  I truly enjoy films where character development is crisp and clean...every single actor/actress in the film has his/her own quirks.  And I loved the cats.  I gave it all 5 stars for its near-perfect editing, script and acting.  I want more!
The end is such a let down. Its like they ran out of ideas or money to finish the film.
I like stalking and exciting movies.  This one seemed slow, but then it was really too dark for me.  Disgusting.  Without a very good plot or excitement.
This movie has an interesting premise: your neighbors are not all they seem. Unfortunately, the script and overall pacing falls short.

the movie felt cut short to me. I wished there would have been a couple more scenes to wrap everything up, or continued the story, which felt unfinished to me. The rest of the movie is so unique that it's still worth watching. Excellent cast!

First, let me say this is a good movie, it's different and has some real WTF moments in it. I would've rated it higher, had I been looking for this, whatever it is. It's not scary, there's no mystery, there's no real investigation of any substance for you to follow. It does twist your mind a few times, and one scene at least should totally gross you out. But, if like me, you're looking for what it's advertised to be, keep looking and come back to this another day.
It was okay, mildly entertaining, I don't think the characters had enough "character". A little predictable and the actress was too "ODD" overplayed I think a little.
Louise savagely murdered her nasty neighbour and framed Victor. She played both Victor and Spencer against each other. Spencer died. What happened to chatterbox Victor??? Well done Louise.
Interestingly entertaining. I loved the plot and characters. Had some nice twists that made the movie very good. Recommend anyone to watch.

I just watched this for the second time, about four months after I saw it originally; my original impressions were confirmed. This is a brilliant little film in my estimation: it manipulates all of our expectations about who these characters are and what "normal" is. Indeed, "normal" doesn't really fit in anywhere, with a sexual serial killer on the loose, a goofy but well-intentioned new neighbor and a heroine who will shock your socks off.

Spencer is charming, smooth and outrageously handsome, but there is something incredibly menacing in his smile and his playful cruelty from the start. (The scene where he "romances" Louise's co-worker from the Chinese restaurant is blood-curdling.) Victor, a nerdy and sweet newcomer to the apartment building, is clumsily gallant and lives in  his delusional desire; Louise is quirky yet deadpan and afectless except when it comes to loving felines, but cold-blooded and willing to go a long, long way to get what she wants. And then there's the awful and hilarious alcoholic neighbor who hates all people and cats and who spouts obscenities non-stop, two cops tracking the serial killer, and two kindly middle-aged women who haven't got a clue about what's going on.

The normal and the abnormal are so seamlessly woven together in this movie that I was somewhat left with my jaw dropping: I really loved the way it creates a hero and a heroine while at the same time it tends to blur the line between what makes a sexually sadistic serial killer different from...everyone else... It's a very funny, chilling, creepy movie; I loved its intelligence.
liked it enough to buy it...liked how they're all a little messed up and the all Canadian cast..pretty neat movie.

For people who may be picking up this film because they enjoyed "The Trotsky" -- be warned! Although the story also takes place in Montreal, and writer/director Jacob Tierney is working with some of the same actors, this story is much darker and its view of human nature is a lot less upbeat -- Jay Baruchel and Emily Hampshire are playing very different characters this time around. Let's face it ... the resident cats are the nicest creatures you encounter in the main setting, a run-down apartment building in the neighbourhood of Notre-Dame-de-Grce, or NDG. As in his previous work, Tierney's unapologetic about the Canadian setting, and doesn't try to pass it off as some generic US city. There are numerous references to the English-French cultural conflicts, in the months during and after the Quebec referendum in 1995. The dreary cold winter helps accentuate the isolation that the building's occupants are experiencing. On the surface, the story would appear to be about the friendships that new arrival Victor (Jay Baruchel) makes when he moves in. But the key characters are all flawed in some way -- hostile, delusional, passive-aggressive -- and inevitably the tense situation deteriorates. I don't want to give away too much, but people who are really turned off by onscreen violence, to the point of having nightmares if things get too graphic, may want to skip the last half of the film. Aside from that, it's a fascinating character study about the interactions of a group of troubled people. Some of them seem to be textbook examples of what psychologists like Robert Hare have been trying to warn us about. There is some comedy, but it's appropriately dark and disturbed. There's an extended nude scene, but given what leads up to it, people may find it more ominous than titillating. Really, by the end of the film I was just grateful that I don't live in that building!

On several movie site I visit, there had been a buzz about an independent Canadian murder mystery film, that was supposed to be quite a thriller with big twist at the end. It sounded like the perfect movie for me and I couldn't wait to see it! Good Neighbors is about an apartment building in Canada that is getting a new tenant named Victor (Jay Baruchel). Victor immediately sees that something isn't right about the new place and soon learns that everyone is on edge because of a serial killer on the loose. A serial killer that I was able to identify ten minutes into the movie. How in the world can anyone, much less a movie fan, call this a thriller with a twist in the end? The killer was obvious from the very beginning and I'm willing to bet the average fourth grader would agree. As for the notion that this is a thriller? Come on, a thriller is supposed to have you on the edge of your seat, not falling asleep in it! The story was slow, sloppy, and predictable, but what about the acting. I generally like Jay Baruchel, but he is a mess in this film. Baruchel is way out of his element here and would probably do best sticking to Apatow comedies. The only bright spot in the film is Emily Hampshire, she's been around a while, but has never been in anything big. Hampshire was terrific and is really the only interesting character in this film. Good Neighbors is a huge disappointment and anyone who tells you otherwise can't be as big a movie fan as they proclaim to be. I can deal with slow moving, I can live with some boring parts here and there, but a painfully predictable story with very below average performances is a recipe for disaster.
Really good story. Very interesting and the end has a great twist. I really enjoyed it and definetly recommend it.

The "not likeable" may be an overstatement - but overall, it is hard to care about what happens (or doesn't) to any of movie's characters.  The acting is bad, and the end unsatisfying - not to mention the overall unplausibility of the plot.  Although one of the other "one star" reviewers suggested the movie was not clear as to who the serial killer was, I thought is was all too obvious. If you find yourself after 20-30 minutes "into" the movie wondering whether you should keep watching, go with your gut & turn "it" off.

For the first 3/4 of the film I was rolling my eyes with disappointment.  I thought it was so predictable.  My prediction about the true identity of the killer was established in the first 5 mins and confirmed by mid-film.  However, if you stick it out, they pull out an impressive twist and the movie actually becomes good.

I have no idea why it's listed in the 'comedy' category.  Drama, thriller...yes and yes.  But there was nothing comedic about it unless you just have a twisted sense of humor and get a kick out of the ending.

My recommendation:  Tough it out 'til the end and you will see a good movie, just don't expect a barrel of laughs.

This movies was pretty good, usually I watch movies and re sell them. I decided to keep this one. It is something that I will watch again. Three English speaking people in France. There is a serial killer on the loose and ofcoarse one of the 3 are the killers.

I really enjoy Canadian produced movies.  Foolproof is perhaps my favorite and I will count this one amongst them.  The movie teaser was misleading but how could an accurate teaser be written for this very quirky movie.  Terrific story, great characters, a versial movie for sure...

I thought this film was, in every way, better than I expected it to be, given the 3 reviews so far.  Its well done from a technical aspect, I liked the actors and thought they were good at their craft, I liked the story and it kept me completely interested.

A predictable, poorly acted, awkward waste of film is what Amazon Prime is offering for free these days.  Since some of the awkwardness was intentional, it saves the movie from being a one star stinker.  Judging by the rest of their most popular Prime instant videos, I will not be renewing my membership.

Saw this movie was just so.  Amazon, Please get some newer movies on board for Prime Members instead of old reruns. I am really getting desperate trying to find a good movie here.  Prime members deserve better.

If you like things wrapped up neatly, then you may find the quirky suspense/comedy Good Neighbours (2010) not entirely satisfying. It's a film where from the start it is not very clear, what kind of story is being told, and when it concludes, some key questions remain unanswered. Set in Montreal in 1995, the story is centered on three people who live in an apartment building, and are each a bit strange in their own particular ways. Major spoilers follow, so proceed at your own risk. Louise (Emmy Hampshire, Snow Cake) a waitress at a Chinese restaurant, spends her spare time caring for her cats, and following the exploits of a serial killer, who's victims come to include one of her coworkers. Louise, who lives on the third floor, is feuding with her bitchy French speaking neighbor Valerie (Anne-Marie Cadieux, Far Side of the Moon), because of the activities of her cats. Affable and quick witted, wheelchair bound Spencer (Scott Speedman, Underworld (2003)) is Louise's friend. He lives on the second floor of a building, which apparently has no elevator. When schoolteacher Victor (Jay Baruchel, She's Out of My League) moves into an apartment on the fourth floor, he begins to alter the existing dynamic, attempting to start a relationship with Louise. Although it isn't true, a delusional Victor tells those close to him, that she is his fiance. The situation changes drastically, when Louise's cats are found dead. Believing that Valerie is responsible, Louise brutally kills her neighbor, in a very messy, nasty, and realistic fashion. This is followed by a sexual assault on the corpse, as her plan is to blame the murder on the notorious serial killer. This unlikely ploy is complicated by both Spencer and Victor, who each have quite different takes on the situation. This leads to a dramatic and somewhat unsetting resolution. The actions of the warped characters, makes for a tale where the pieces don't fit together very nicely. Victor is kind of a nut case who does odd things, like attempting to install a wheelchair lift on the staircase, as a "surprise" gift to Spencer. A cold calculating killer, Louise is a strange creature, whose selfish actions and cunning, drive much of what happens. Spencer has his own dark secrets, living some farfetched double life. How the serial killer really figures in isn't clear, as things end rather conveniently, which may leave some confused, or perhaps frustrated. Despite any issues with the story, the acting performances are very solid, drawing you into a world with assorted odd characters. Standing out is Emmy Hampshire's wide ranging and dynamic performance, as a woman capable of great ruthlessness, who seems to relate best to cats rather than people.

If you like things wrapped up neatly, then you may find the quirky suspense/comedy Good Neighbours (2010) not entirely satisfying. It's a film where from the start it is not very clear, what kind of story is being told, and when it concludes, some key questions remain unanswered. When schoolteacher Victor (Jay Baruchel, She's Out of My League) moves into an apartment on the fourth floor, he begins to alter the existing dynamic, attempting to start a relationship with Louise. Although it isn't true, a delusional Victor tells those close to him, that she is his fiance. The situation changes drastically, when Louise's cats are found dead. Believing that Valerie is responsible, Louise brutally kills her neighbor, in a very messy, nasty, and realistic fashion. This is followed by a sexual assault on the corpse, as her plan is to blame the murder on the notorious serial killer. This unlikely ploy is complicated by both Spencer and Victor, who each have quite different takes on the situation. This leads to a dramatic and somewhat unsetting resolution. The actions of the warped characters, makes for a tale where the pieces don't fit together very nicely. Victor is kind of a nut case who does odd things, like attempting to install a wheelchair lift on the staircase, as a "surprise" gift to Spencer. A cold calculating killer, Louise is a strange creature, whose selfish actions and cunning, drive much of what happens. Spencer has his own dark secrets, living some farfetched double life. How the serial killer really figures in isn't clear, as things end rather conveniently, which may leave some confused, or perhaps frustrated. Despite any issues with the story, the acting performances are very solid, drawing you into a world with assorted odd characters. Standing out is Emmy Hampshire's wide ranging and dynamic performance, as a woman capable of great ruthlessness, who seems to relate best to cats rather than people. For Prime members looking for some dark suspense, Good Neighbours might be worth your time.

I have such a crush on Scott Speedman and Jay Baruchel. So naturally, I had to own this since they both star in it. I really liked this film, it's different from other thrillers. Has it's scares too. I would recommend this to anyone :)

The characters are intresting and I liked the plot. I'm a cat lover too but this movie takes the meaning "Crazy Cat Lady" to a whole different level.

I saw this movie on HDNet Movies. I missed the last 30 minutes. I looked for several months trying to locate movie in a store. Finally after much frustration I found it on Amazon. I  bought so I could see the last 30 minutes of the movie. What a shocker. It was a good movie with a wild ending.

I don't know where this came from. I have no recollection of it but I'm glad this entered my radar. It's a tight, nifty package of a movie.

Set in Quebec during the holidays, and while a vote is taking place on whether or not they should secede from Canada, a few residents of an apartment building are nervous over the fact a serial killer is on the loose in their neighborhood. Scott Speedman as Spencer is in a wheelchair due to a car accident. Jay Baruchel as Victor, is an elementary school teacher just back from China and new to the building. Emily Hampshire as Loise waits tables at the local Chinese restaurant and owns two way cool cats. Their lives intersect in a quirky way as they grapple with the varying things going on around them.

This is a darkly funny movie. It's laced with good characters. The two cats have an enormous amount of personality and the story turns in some unexpected ways. I was fairly certain on the killer's identity but that turns out not to be as important as the way things play out. You find out who he is pretty early on in the third act so there is nearly another half hour for other things to happen. Speedman is good. He walks a fine line between being glib and being just plain nasty. I liked Emily Hamshire in "Snow Cake" and she's equally good here. Her relationship with her cats really adds quirk to the story. Jay Barushel might be playing the schlub card a bit too strongly but he's still good.

I found this to be written well, directed well, acted well and sporting a good music score. It all moved at an even clip so I wasn't looking at my watch. This might not be a great movie but it's great entertainment.

For our Canadian friends the original title is "Neighbours."  Scott Speedman and Jay Baruchel are pretty well known by American films and TV shows, but I don't ever recall seeing Emily Hampshire previously.  Together they are neighbors in a Montreal apartment building at a time when a serial killer is on the loose.  He targets women, ultimately raping and slitting their throats.  All 3 main characters are weird on the surface.  Louise (Hampshire) has an unusual affection for cats.  Very unusual.  Victor is the newest tenant and is one of those guys who just try too hard to be friends.  He also has eyes for Louise.  Spencer (Speedman) is in a wheelchair, but is a bit too friendly to be real.

All are tormented by a nutty (even by their standards) French speaking, cat hating neighbor who's on the verge of a breakdown.  The film switches gears midway to become the darkest of comedies including a gruesome plot to kill the French lady.  Eww, just thinking about it.  Unfortunately, the film is as unstable as the neighbors.  Although there are some interesting, if unsettling concepts, it's all just a little too far out there for my taste.

This is a strange story of three neighbors in Quebec, all of whom are not what or whom they appear to be.  One is in a wheelchair...but should he be?  Another is a new guy who talks too much and tells people he is engaged to the third one but he isn't. The third is a young woman engaged in battle with another woman who hates the first one's cats and has marital troubles too.  All of these people and situations come together, culminating in some violence that I will not spoil here.

It's not uncommon for the residents in an apartment to have a falling out over the problem of pets. There's always one indulgent pet lover in the crowd - and always someone who can't stand the sight of anything with fur. But in this case, the conflict reveals some darker, more dangerous twists of character in each of these "good neighbors."

The first time I watched this film, I thought it was a little disjointed and left the motives of some of the key players rather poorly explained. But when I viewed it through a second time, giving it my full attention, I saw that there was both rhyme and reason to this suspense drama, and that it was actually closely plotted.

There's a singularly gruesome, memorable murder that takes place here. At the end, it's easy to overlook the fact that the case might not really be closed - that at least one of the characters faces a further hazard. And therein hangs a tail...
Meh, this was just okay. Way too slow paced for my taste.
